list_bullet_points.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity Regulation
list_bullet_points.text: Recently, cybercriminals have sought to exploit technological vulnerabilities to gain access to sensitive electronic data. Cybercriminals can cause significant financial losses for DFS regulated entities as well as for New York consumers whose private information may be revealed and/or stolen for illicit purposes.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point describes the threat posed by cybercriminals to DFS regulated entities and New York consumers.
list_bullet_points.context: The context explains the increased threats posed by cybercriminals exploiting technological vulnerabilities.

list_bullet_points.name: Regulatory Minimum Standards
list_bullet_points.text: Given the seriousness of the issue and the risk to all regulated entities, certain regulatory minimum standards are warranted, while not being overly prescriptive so that cybersecurity programs can match the relevant risks and keep pace with technological advances.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point highlights the need for regulatory minimum standards for cybersecurity.
list_bullet_points.context: It discusses the balance between regulation and flexibility in designing cybersecurity programs.

list_bullet_points.name: Senior Management Responsibility
list_bullet_points.text: Senior management must take this issue seriously and be responsible for the organization’s cybersecurity program and file an annual certification confirming compliance with these regulations.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point states the responsibility of senior management in the cybersecurity program and compliance certification.
list_bullet_points.context: The role of senior management in ensuring and certifying compliance with cybersecurity regulations.

list_bullet_points.name: Urgency in Adopting Cybersecurity Program
list_bullet_points.text: It is critical for all regulated institutions that have not yet done so to move swiftly and urgently to adopt a cybersecurity program and for all regulated entities to be subject to minimum standards with respect to their programs.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point emphasizes the urgency for all regulated institutions to adopt cybersecurity programs.
list_bullet_points.context: The need for swift action in adopting cybersecurity measures is emphasized.

list_bullet_points.name: Potential risks and priority
list_bullet_points.text: 2 estimates of potential risk to our financial services industry are stark. Adoption of the program outlined in these regulations is a priority for New York State.
list_bullet_points.description: Recognizes the significant risks faced by the financial services industry and highlights the priority status of the cybersecurity program in New York State.
list_bullet_points.context: Highlights the importance and priority of adopting the cybersecurity program to mitigate risks in the financial services industry.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Affiliate
list_bullet_points.text: (a) Affiliate means any person that controls, is controlled by or is under common control with another person. For purposes of this subdivision, control means the possession, direct or indirect, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of a person, whether through the ownership of stock of such person or otherwise.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines 'Affiliate' in the context of control and management within the regulatory framework.
list_bullet_points.context: Focuses on outlining key definitions crucial to understanding the scope of the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Authorized User
list_bullet_points.text: (b) Authorized user means any employee, contractor, agent or other person that participates in the business operations of a covered entity and is authorized to access and use any information systems and data of the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Clarifies who is considered an 'Authorized user' under the cybersecurity regulations.
list_bullet_points.context: Provides clarity on who within an organization is permitted to access data and systems based on authorization.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of CISO
list_bullet_points.text: (c) Chief Information Security Officer or CISO means a qualified individual responsible for overseeing and implementing a covered entity’s cybersecurity program and enforcing its cybersecurity policy.
list_bullet_points.description: Specifies the role and responsibilities of the Chief Information Security Officer within the cybersecurity framework.
list_bullet_points.context: Details the leadership role necessary for managing a cybersecurity program within a covered entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Class A Company
list_bullet_points.text: (d) Class A company means a covered entity with at least $20,000,000 in gross annual revenue in each of the last two fiscal years from all business operations of the covered entity and the business operations in this State of the covered entity’s affiliates and: (1) over 2,000 employees averaged over the last two fiscal years, including employees of both the covered entity and all of its affiliates no matter where located; or (2) over $1,000,000,000 in gross annual revenue in each of the last two fiscal years from all business operations of the covered entity and all of its affiliates no matter where located. For purposes of this subdivision, when calculating the number of employees and gross annual revenue, affiliates shall include only those that share information systems, cybersecurity resources or all or any part of a cybersecurity program with the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines what constitutes a 'Class A Company' in terms of revenue and employee thresholds, including calculations involving affiliates.
list_bullet_points.context: Sets the criteria for categorizing a financial services entity as a 'Class A Company' under the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Covered Entity
list_bullet_points.text: (e) Covered entity means any person operating under or required to operate under a license, registration, charter, certificate, permit, accreditation or similar authorization under the Banking Law, the Insurance Law or the Financial Services Law, regardless of whether the covered entity is also regulated by other government agencies.
list_bullet_points.description: Describes 'Covered entity' as entities operating under specific legal authorizations in the financial sector.
list_bullet_points.context: Clarifies the scope of entities obliged to comply with the cybersecurity regulations.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Cybersecurity Event
list_bullet_points.text: (f) Cybersecurity event means any act or attempt, successful or unsuccessful, to gain unauthorized access to, disrupt or misuse an information system or information stored on such information system.
list_bullet_points.description: Outlines what constitutes a 'Cybersecurity event' involving information systems.
list_bullet_points.context: Emphasizes the types of activities that are considered threats to information security under the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Cybersecurity Incident
list_bullet_points.text: (g) Cybersecurity incident means a cybersecurity event that has occurred at the covered entity, its affiliates, or a third-party service provider that:
list_bullet_points.description: Defines 'Cybersecurity incident' focusing on its occurrence at covered entities or third parties.
list_bullet_points.context: Delineates the scope of incidents impacting entities within the regulatory framework.

list_bullet_points.name: Notification to government bodies
list_bullet_points.text: (1) impacts the covered entity and requires the covered entity to notify any government body, self-regulatory agency or any other supervisory body;
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for covered entities to notify specific bodies if certain impacts occur.
list_bullet_points.context: Notification obligations in case of significant cybersecurity events.

list_bullet_points.name: Material harm likelihood
list_bullet_points.text: (2) has a reasonable likelihood of materially harming any material part of the normal operation(s) of the covered entity;
list_bullet_points.description: Potential threats that are likely to cause material harm to operations.
list_bullet_points.context: Definition for determining significant impact on operations.

list_bullet_points.name: Ransomware deployment
list_bullet_points.text: (3) results in the deployment of ransomware within a material part of the covered entity’s information systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Specification of ransomware as a notable cybersecurity event.
list_bullet_points.context: Understanding triggers for notifications based on cybersecurity threats.

list_bullet_points.name: Independent audit definition
list_bullet_points.text: (h) Independent audit means an audit conducted by internal or external auditors free to make decisions not influenced by the covered entity being audited or by its owners, managers or employees.
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of what constitutes an independent audit.
list_bullet_points.context: Clarification of independence criteria for audits.

list_bullet_points.name: Information system definition
list_bullet_points.text: (i) Information system means a discrete set of electronic information resources organized for the collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing, dissemination or disposition of electronic information, as well as any specialized system such as industrial/process controls systems, telephone switching and private branch exchange systems, and environmental control systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of what constitutes an information system.
list_bullet_points.context: Explanation of components and types of information systems within the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Multi-factor authentication
list_bullet_points.text: (j) Multi-factor authentication means authentication through verification of at least two of the following types of authentication factors: (1) knowledge factors, such as a password; (2) possession factors, such as a token; or (3) inherence factors, such as a biometric characteristic.
list_bullet_points.description: Description of the components that make up multi-factor authentication.
list_bullet_points.context: Detailing requirements for authentication security within covered entities.

list_bullet_points.name: Nonpublic information definition
list_bullet_points.text: (k) Nonpublic information means all electronic information that is not publicly available information and is: (1) business related information of a covered entity the tampering with which, or unauthorized disclosure, access or use of which, would cause a material adverse impact to the business, operations or security of the covered entity;
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of nonpublic information related to business impact.
list_bullet_points.context: Clarification of what qualifies as nonpublic information in the context of cybersecurity.

list_bullet_points.name: Individual identifying information
list_bullet_points.text: (2) any information concerning an individual which because of name, number, personal mark, or other identifier can be used to identify such individual, in combination with any one or more of the following data elements: (i) social security number; (ii) drivers’ license number or non-driver identification card number; (iii) account number, credit or debit card number; (iv) any security code, access code or password that would permit access to an individual’s financial account;
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of information that identifies an individual according to the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Understanding privacy and confidentiality requirements for individual data.

list_bullet_points.name: Biometric Records
list_bullet_points.text: (v) biometric records;
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of what constitutes biometric records.
list_bullet_points.context: This is part of the specification of types of personal data that are protected under the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Health Information
list_bullet_points.text: any information or data, except age or gender, in any form or medium created by or derived from a health care provider or an individual and that relates to: (i) the past, present or future physical, mental or behavioral health or condition of any individual or a member of the individual's family; (ii) the provision of health care to any individual; or (iii) payment for the provision of health care to any individual.
list_bullet_points.description: Definition of health-related information covered by the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies what constitutes the health information that must be protected.

list_bullet_points.name: Penetration Testing
list_bullet_points.text: Penetration testing means testing the security of information systems by attempting to circumvent or defeat the security features of an information system by authorizing attempted penetration of databases or controls from outside or inside the covered entity’s information systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Explanation of penetration testing as a method to evaluate information system security.
list_bullet_points.context: Describes a method used to test the robustness of cybersecurity measures in place.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Person
list_bullet_points.text: Person means any individual or entity, including but not limited to any partnership, corporation, branch, agency or association.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines what constitutes a 'person' under this regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Clarifies the scope of who or what entities are covered by the term 'person' in the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Privileged Account
list_bullet_points.text: Privileged account means any authorized user account or service account that can be used to perform security-relevant functions that ordinary users are not authorized to perform, including but not limited to the ability to add, change or remove other accounts, or make configuration changes to information systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines privileged accounts and their capabilities.
list_bullet_points.context: Sets the parameters for accounts with elevated security privileges within an organization.

list_bullet_points.name: Publicly Available Information
list_bullet_points.text: Publicly available information means any information that a covered entity has a reasonable basis to believe is lawfully made available to the general public from: Federal, State or local government records; widely distributed media; or disclosures to the general public that are required to be made by Federal, State or local law.
list_bullet_points.description: Clarifies what constitutes publicly available information according to the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Outlines the scope of data that can be considered public and the due diligence required to determine its accessibility.

list_bullet_points.name: Risk Assessment
list_bullet_points.text: Risk assessment means the process of identifying, estimating and prioritizing cybersecurity risks to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image and reputation), organizational assets, individuals, customers, consumers, other organizations and critical infrastructure resulting from the operation of an information system.
list_bullet_points.description: Details the risk assessment process required for cybersecurity.
list_bullet_points.context: Describes the necessary evaluations to understand cybersecurity risks impacting an organization.

list_bullet_points.name: Senior Governing Body
list_bullet_points.text: Senior governing body means the board of directors (or an appropriate committee thereof) or equivalent governing body or, if neither of those exist, the senior officer or officers of a covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines the senior governing body's role in cybersecurity governance.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies who holds ultimate responsibility for cybersecurity matters within an organization.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Program Responsibility
list_bullet_points.text: entity responsible for the covered entity’s cybersecurity program. For any cybersecurity program or part of a cybersecurity program adopted from an affiliate under section 500.2(d) of this Part, the senior governing body may be that of the affiliate.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point emphasizes who is responsible for the cybersecurity program, including the role of the senior governing body in cases where the program is adopted from an affiliate.
list_bullet_points.context: The entity responsible for managing and securing a covered entity's cybersecurity program, possibly including an affiliate's board.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Senior Officer
list_bullet_points.text: Senior officer(s) means the senior individual or individuals (acting collectively or as a committee) responsible for the management, operations, security, information systems, compliance and/or risk of a covered entity, including a branch or agency of a foreign banking organization subject to this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point defines the term 'Senior Officer' in the context of the cybersecurity regulation, highlighting their responsibilities across various aspects of a covered entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Provides clarity on the role and responsibilities of senior officers in the regulation, which could extend to branches of foreign banks.

list_bullet_points.name: Definition of Third-party Service Provider
list_bullet_points.text: Third-party service provider(s) means a person that: (1) is not an affiliate of the covered entity; (2) is not a governmental entity; (3) provides services to the covered entity; and (4) maintains, processes or otherwise is permitted access to nonpublic information through its provision of services to the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines what constitutes a third-party service provider and their access to nonpublic information in the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Describes criteria for third-party service providers, ensuring non-affiliates providing services with access to sensitive data are clearly identified.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Program Requirements
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall maintain a cybersecurity program designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity and availability of the covered entity’s information systems and nonpublic information stored on those information systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Highlights the requirement for covered entities to have a cybersecurity program protecting vital aspects of information systems and data.
list_bullet_points.context: Establishes baseline expectations for covered entities regarding maintaining suitable cybersecurity measures.

list_bullet_points.name: Risk-Based Cybersecurity Program Design
list_bullet_points.text: The cybersecurity program shall be based on the covered entity’s risk assessment and designed to perform the following core cybersecurity functions: (1) identify and assess internal and external cybersecurity risks that may threaten the security or integrity of nonpublic information stored on the covered entity’s information systems; (2) use defensive infrastructure and the implementation of policies and procedures to protect the covered entity’s information systems, and the nonpublic information stored on those information systems, from unauthorized access, use or other malicious acts; (3) detect cybersecurity events; (4) respond to identified or detected cybersecurity events to mitigate any negative effects; (5) recover from cybersecurity events and restore normal operations and services; and (6) fulfill applicable regulatory reporting obligations.
list_bullet_points.description: Details the design criteria for a cybersecurity program based on risk assessment. It outlines specific cybersecurity functions.
list_bullet_points.context: Provides an overview of the structured approach expected for designing cybersecurity programs aligned with risk assessment.

list_bullet_points.name: Independent Cybersecurity Audits
list_bullet_points.text: Each class A company shall design and conduct independent audits of its cybersecurity program based on its risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.description: Class A companies are required to perform independent audits of their cybersecurity programs, tailored to their risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation discussing the expectations for class A companies regarding cybersecurity audits.

list_bullet_points.name: Adoption of Affiliates' Cybersecurity Programs
list_bullet_points.text: A covered entity may meet the requirement(s) of this Part by adopting the relevant and applicable provisions of a cybersecurity program maintained by an affiliate, provided that such provisions satisfy the requirements of this Part, as applicable to the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities can adopt cybersecurity programs from affiliates if they meet the requirements of this regulation and are applicable to the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation on how covered entities can leverage existing cybersecurity programs from affiliates.

list_bullet_points.name: Availability of Cybersecurity Documentation
list_bullet_points.text: All documentation and information relevant to the covered entity’s cybersecurity program, including the relevant and applicable provisions of a cybersecurity program maintained by an affiliate and adopted by the covered entity, shall be made available to the superintendent upon request.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities must provide all cybersecurity documentation to the superintendent upon request.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation instructions on documentation availability requirements.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Policy Requirements
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall implement and maintain a written policy or policies, approved at least annually by a senior officer or the covered entity’s senior governing body for the protection of its information systems and nonpublic information stored on those information systems.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities must have a formal, senior-approved cybersecurity policy reviewed annually.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation requirements for maintaining and approving cybersecurity policies.

list_bullet_points.name: Risk Assessment-Based Policies and Procedures
list_bullet_points.text: Procedures shall be developed, documented and implemented in accordance with the written policy or policies. The cybersecurity policy or policies and procedures shall be based on the covered entity’s risk assessment and address, at a minimum, the following areas to the extent applicable to the covered entity’s operations.
list_bullet_points.description: Cybersecurity policies and procedures must be grounded in risk assessment and cover specified areas relevant to the entity’s operations.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation stressing on risk assessment-based policy and procedure formulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Areas to Address in Cybersecurity Policies
list_bullet_points.text: The cybersecurity policy or policies and procedures shall be based on the covered entity’s risk assessment and address, at a minimum, the following areas to the extent applicable to the covered entity’s operations: information security; data governance, classification and retention; asset inventory, device management and end of life management; access controls, including remote access and identity management; business continuity and disaster recovery planning and resources; systems operations and availability concerns; systems and network security and monitoring; security awareness and training; systems and application security and development and quality assurance; physical security and environmental controls; customer data privacy; vendor and third-party service provider management;
list_bullet_points.description: A set of minimum areas that cybersecurity policies and procedures should address, based on the covered entity’s risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.context: NYDFS Cybersecurity Regulation listing specific areas to include in cybersecurity policies.

list_bullet_points.name: Designation of Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall designate a CISO. The CISO may be employed by the covered entity, one of its affiliates or a third-party service provider.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for financial entities to appoint a Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) either internally, through an affiliate, or a third-party service.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: Responsibilities when CISO is from Third-party or Affiliate
list_bullet_points.text: If the CISO is employed by a third-party service provider or an affiliate, the covered entity shall: (1) retain responsibility for compliance with this Part; (2) designate a senior member of the covered entity’s personnel responsible for direction and oversight of the third-party service provider; and (3) require the third-party service provider or affiliate to maintain a cybersecurity program that protects the covered entity in accordance with the requirements of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Outlined responsibilities for covered entities when their CISO is sourced from a third-party or affiliate.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: CISO's Annual Report
list_bullet_points.text: The CISO of each covered entity shall report in writing at least annually to the senior governing body on the covered entity’s cybersecurity program, including to the extent applicable...
list_bullet_points.description: CISO is required to provide an annual written report on the cybersecurity program to the governing body.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: Contents of CISO's Report
list_bullet_points.text: including to the extent applicable: (1) the confidentiality of nonpublic information and the integrity and security of the covered entity’s information systems; (2) the covered entity’s cybersecurity policies and procedures; (3) material cybersecurity risks to the covered entity; (4) overall effectiveness of the covered entity’s cybersecurity program; (5) material cybersecurity events involving the covered entity during the time period addressed by the report; and (6) plans for remediating material inadequacies.
list_bullet_points.description: Specific content requirements for the CISO's annual report to the senior governing body.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: Timely Reporting of Cybersecurity Issues by CISO
list_bullet_points.text: The CISO shall timely report to the senior governing body or senior officer(s) on material cybersecurity issues, such as significant cybersecurity events and significant changes to the covered entity’s cybersecurity program.
list_bullet_points.description: Mandate for CISO to promptly inform the senior governing body of major cybersecurity issues.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: Oversight by Senior Governing Body
list_bullet_points.text: The senior governing body of the covered entity shall exercise oversight of the covered entity’s cybersecurity risk management, including by:
list_bullet_points.description: The role of the senior governing body in overseeing cybersecurity risk management.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.4 Cybersecurity governance

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity oversight understanding
list_bullet_points.text: (1) having sufficient understanding of cybersecurity-related matters to exercise such oversight, which may include the use of advisors;
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities must have sufficient understanding of cybersecurity-related matters to exercise oversight effectively. This may include utilizing advisors.
list_bullet_points.context: The regulation emphasizes the importance of understanding cybersecurity to oversee effectively, possibly with help from advisors.

list_bullet_points.name: Development of cybersecurity program
list_bullet_points.text: (2) requiring the covered entity’s executive management or its designees to develop, implement and maintain the covered entity’s cybersecurity program;
list_bullet_points.description: Executive management or designees must be responsible for developing, implementing, and maintaining a cybersecurity program.
list_bullet_points.context: This highlights the role of executive management in maintaining a cybersecurity program.

list_bullet_points.name: Regular review of cybersecurity matters
list_bullet_points.text: (3) regularly receiving and reviewing management reports about cybersecurity matters;
list_bullet_points.description: Regularly receive and review reports on cybersecurity matters.
list_bullet_points.context: The requirement for regular management review of cybersecurity issues to stay informed and proactive.

list_bullet_points.name: Resource allocation for cybersecurity
list_bullet_points.text: (4) confirming that the covered entity’s management has allocated sufficient resources to implement and maintain an effective cybersecurity program.
list_bullet_points.description: Management must confirm resource allocation for effective cybersecurity.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensuring that resources are properly allocated to maintain security programs.

list_bullet_points.name: Vulnerability management policies
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall, in accordance with its risk assessment, develop and implement written policies and procedures for vulnerability management that are designed to assess and maintain the effectiveness of its cybersecurity program.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities must create and implement written policies for vulnerability management based on risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.context: This details the requirement for written policies in managing vulnerabilities.

list_bullet_points.name: Conduct penetration testing
list_bullet_points.text: (1) penetration testing of their information systems from both inside and outside the information systems’ boundaries by a qualified internal or external party at least annually;
list_bullet_points.description: Annual penetration testing of information systems by a qualified party is required both internally and externally.
list_bullet_points.context: The requirement for regular testing to identify vulnerabilities within and outside systems.

list_bullet_points.name: Automated scans and manual reviews for vulnerabilities
list_bullet_points.text: (2) automated scans of information systems, and a manual review of systems not covered by such scans, for the purpose of discovering, analyzing and reporting vulnerabilities at a frequency determined by the risk assessment, and promptly after any material system changes;
list_bullet_points.description: Conduct automated and manual reviews to assess system vulnerabilities, adjusting frequency based on risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.context: A proactive approach to identifying vulnerabilities through scanning and reviews.

list_bullet_points.name: Security vulnerabilities monitoring process
list_bullet_points.text: (b) are promptly informed of new security vulnerabilities by having a monitoring process in place;
list_bullet_points.description: There must be a process to promptly inform the entity of new security vulnerabilities.
list_bullet_points.context: Implementing monitoring processes to stay updated on vulnerabilities.

list_bullet_points.name: Timely remediation of vulnerabilities
list_bullet_points.text: (c) timely remediate vulnerabilities, giving priority to vulnerabilities based on the risk they pose to the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Vulnerabilities should be remediated timely with priority given based on risk.
list_bullet_points.context: Addressing vulnerabilities in an order that reflects the risk they pose.

list_bullet_points.name: Maintain audit trails
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall securely maintain systems that, to the extent applicable and based on its risk assessment: (a)(1) are designed to reconstruct material financial transactions sufficient to support normal operations and obligations of the covered entity;
list_bullet_points.description: Secure maintenance of systems for reconstructing financial transactions is required to support operations.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensuring systems can support reconstructing financial transactions to maintain operations.

list_bullet_points.name: Audit trails for cybersecurity events
list_bullet_points.text: include audit trails designed to detect and respond to cybersecurity events that have a reasonable likelihood of materially harming any material part of the normal operations of the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for audit trails to detect and respond to significant cybersecurity events.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures that cybersecurity events that could harm operations are tracked and managed.

list_bullet_points.name: Record maintenance for audit trails
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall maintain records required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section for not fewer than five years and shall maintain records required by paragraph (a)(2) of this section for not fewer than three years.
list_bullet_points.description: Mandates record retention timeframes for records related to audit trails.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies the duration for which records of audit trails must be maintained by covered entities.

list_bullet_points.name: Access privileges based on risk assessment
list_bullet_points.text: As part of its cybersecurity program, based on the covered entity’s risk assessment each covered entity shall: limit user access privileges to information systems that provide access to nonpublic information to only those necessary to perform the user’s job;
list_bullet_points.description: Addresses limiting access privileges to only those necessary according to job roles, based on a risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures user access is restricted appropriately to protect nonpublic information.

list_bullet_points.name: Limitation on privileged accounts
list_bullet_points.text: limit the number of privileged accounts and limit the access functions of privileged accounts to only those necessary to perform the user’s job;
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement to restrict the number and functionality of privileged accounts.
list_bullet_points.context: Aims to control and limit privileged access within the entity to necessary functions only.

list_bullet_points.name: Periodic review of user access privileges
list_bullet_points.text: periodically, but at a minimum annually, review all user access privileges and remove or disable accounts and access that are no longer necessary;
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for regular review of user access privileges and removal of unnecessary access.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures that unused or unnecessary user access is removed or disabled to enhance security.

list_bullet_points.name: Remote control protocols
list_bullet_points.text: disable or securely configure all protocols that permit remote control of devices; and
list_bullet_points.description: Mandate to disable or securely configure remote control protocols.
list_bullet_points.context: Addresses potential security risks associated with remote control access to systems.

list_bullet_points.name: Termination of access upon departure
list_bullet_points.text: promptly terminate access following departures.
list_bullet_points.description: Ensures the immediate termination of access for users who have left the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Prevents former employees or users from retaining access to systems.

list_bullet_points.name: Password policy standards
list_bullet_points.text: To the extent passwords are employed as a method of authentication, the covered entity shall implement a written password policy that meets industry standards.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for password policies to adhere to industry standards.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures the security of password-based authentication methods through standardization.

list_bullet_points.name: Privileged access monitoring for Class A
list_bullet_points.text: Each class A company shall monitor privileged access activity and shall implement: a privileged access management solution; and
list_bullet_points.description: Class A companies are mandated to monitor privileged access and implement management solutions.
list_bullet_points.context: Enhances control and oversight of privileged access activities within Class A companies.

list_bullet_points.name: Blocking commonly used passwords
list_bullet_points.text: an automated method of blocking commonly used passwords for all accounts on information systems owned or controlled by the class A company and wherever feasible for all other accounts.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for Class A companies to block commonly used passwords, with an alternative control for infeasibility.
list_bullet_points.context: Aims to improve account security by preventing the use of weak, common passwords.

list_bullet_points.name: Secure development practices for in-house applications
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity’s cybersecurity program shall include written procedures, guidelines and standards designed to ensure the use of secure development practices for in-house developed applications utilized by the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point mandates the establishment of secure development practices for applications developed internally by the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.8 Application Security Section, subsection (a)

list_bullet_points.name: Evaluation of externally developed applications
list_bullet_points.text: procedures for evaluating, assessing or testing the security of externally developed applications utilized by the covered entity within the context of the covered entity’s technology environment.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point emphasizes the need to assess the security of externally sourced applications.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.8 Application Security Section, subsection (a)

list_bullet_points.name: Annual review by CISO
list_bullet_points.text: All such procedures, guidelines and standards shall be reviewed, assessed and updated as necessary by the CISO (or a qualified designee) of the covered entity at least annually.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point requires that the cybersecurity procedures, guidelines, and standards be reviewed and updated annually by the CISO or a qualified designee.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.8 Application Security Section, subsection (b)

list_bullet_points.name: Periodic risk assessment
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall conduct a periodic risk assessment of the covered entity’s information systems sufficient to inform the design of the cybersecurity program as required by this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: This requires covered entities to perform regular risk assessments to inform their cybersecurity programs.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (a)

list_bullet_points.name: Annual review and update of risk assessments
list_bullet_points.text: Such risk assessment shall be reviewed and updated as reasonably necessary, but at a minimum annually, and whenever a change in the business or technology causes a material change to the covered entity’s cyber risk.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point mandates regular and at least annual reviews and updates of risk assessments, especially after significant changes.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (a)

list_bullet_points.name: Revision of controls
list_bullet_points.text: The covered entity’s risk assessment shall allow for revision of controls to respond to technological developments and evolving threats.
list_bullet_points.description: This point emphasizes the dynamic revision of controls in response to new technology and threats.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (a)

list_bullet_points.name: Documentation and written policies
list_bullet_points.text: The risk assessment shall be carried out in accordance with written policies and procedures and shall be documented.
list_bullet_points.description: Documenting the risk assessment process and maintaining written policies is required.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (b)

list_bullet_points.name: Criteria for cybersecurity risk evaluation
list_bullet_points.text: criteria for the evaluation and categorization of identified cybersecurity risks or threats facing the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: This involves having criteria for assessing and categorizing identified risks.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (b)(1)

list_bullet_points.name: Assessment of confidentiality, integrity, security, and availability
list_bullet_points.text: criteria for the assessment of the confidentiality, integrity, security and availability of the covered entity’s information systems and nonpublic information.
list_bullet_points.description: This requires establishing criteria for evaluating key cybersecurity attributes of the entity's systems and information.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (b)(2)

list_bullet_points.name: Risk mitigation and acceptance
list_bullet_points.text: requirements describing how identified risks will be mitigated or accepted based on the risk assessment and how the cybersecurity program will address the risks.
list_bullet_points.description: There should be procedures describing how risks are managed or accepted, and how these are addressed in the cybersecurity program.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.9 Risk Assessment Section, subsection (b)(3)

list_bullet_points.name: Utilization of qualified cybersecurity personnel
list_bullet_points.text: utilize qualified cybersecurity personnel of the covered entity, an affiliate or a third-party service provider sufficient to manage the covered entity’s cybersecurity risks.
list_bullet_points.description: This mandates the use of qualified personnel, either in-house or from third-party services, to manage cybersecurity risks.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.10 Cybersecurity Personnel Section, subsection (a)(1)

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Personnel Training
list_bullet_points.text:
provide cybersecurity personnel with cybersecurity updates and training sufficient to 
address relevant cybersecurity risks
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for updating and training cybersecurity personnel to address risks.
list_bullet_points.context: This bullet point falls under the personnel training requirements for cybersecurity preparedness.

list_bullet_points.name: Key Personnel Knowledge Maintenance
list_bullet_points.text:
verify that key cybersecurity personnel take steps to maintain current knowledge of 
changing cybersecurity threats and countermeasures.
list_bullet_points.description: Ensuring key personnel are keeping up-to-date with current cybersecurity threats.
list_bullet_points.context: Focuses on the continuous education of key cybersecurity staff to keep abreast of threats and countermeasures.

list_bullet_points.name: Third-party Assistance
list_bullet_points.text:
A covered entity may choose to utilize an affiliate or qualified third-party service provider to 
assist in complying with the requirements set forth in this Part, subject to the requirements set 
forth in sections 500.4 and 500.11 of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Utilization of third-party service providers for compliance can be an option for covered entities.
list_bullet_points.context: Explains how third-party affiliates can assist in fulfilling compliance requirements.

list_bullet_points.name: Third-party Provider Security Policy
list_bullet_points.text:
Each covered entity shall implement written policies and procedures designed to ensure the 
security of information systems and nonpublic information that are accessible to, or held by, 
third-party service providers.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement to ensure security policies are in place for third-party providers.
list_bullet_points.context: This is about ensuring third-party companies maintain a sufficient security standard as per the entity's policies.

list_bullet_points.name: Identification and Risk Assessment of Third-party Providers
list_bullet_points.text: the identification and risk assessment of third-party service providers
list_bullet_points.description: Entities must identify and assess the risk posed by third-party service providers.
list_bullet_points.context: Part of the requirement for maintaining security in third-party partnerships.

list_bullet_points.name: Minimum Cybersecurity Practices for Third-party Providers
list_bullet_points.text:
minimum cybersecurity practices required to be met by such third-party service 
providers in order for them to do business with the covered entity
list_bullet_points.description: Setting cybersecurity practice requirements for third-parties to engage in business.
list_bullet_points.context: Details the cybersecurity standards third-party providers must meet.

list_bullet_points.name: Due Diligence for Third-party Providers
list_bullet_points.text:
due diligence processes used to evaluate the adequacy of cybersecurity practices of 
such third-party service providers
list_bullet_points.description: Processes to evaluate the cybersecurity capabilities of third-party service providers.
list_bullet_points.context: Part of ongoing risk assessment activities for third-party relationships.

list_bullet_points.name: Periodic Assessment of Third-party Providers
list_bullet_points.text:
periodic assessment of such third-party service providers based on the risk they 
present and the continued adequacy of their cybersecurity practices.
list_bullet_points.description: Regular evaluation of third-party service providers' cybersecurity methods and risks.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures that third-party cybersecurity practices remain adequate over time.

list_bullet_points.text:
the third-party service provider’s policies and procedures for access controls,

list_bullet_points.description: Guidelines on access control measures to be followed by third-party service providers.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures third-party providers have strict access management in place.

the third-party service provider’s policies and procedures for use of encryption as

list_bullet_points.description: Mandates the use of encryption by third-party providers to protect data.
list_bullet_points.context: Providing encryption standards to be met by third parties handling sensitive information.

notice to be provided to the covered entity in the event of a cybersecurity event

nonpublic information being held by the third-party service provider
list_bullet_points.description: Notification requirements for cybersecurity incidents affecting covered entities' information.
list_bullet_points.context: Outlines the obligations of third-party providers to report cybersecurity incidents.

(4) representations and warranties addressing the third-party service provider’s

list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.text:

systems of a covered entity, unless the covered entity qualifies for a limited exemption pursuant 
to section 500.19(a) of this Part in which case multi-factor authentication shall be utilized for:
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point emphasizes the requirement for multi-factor authentication for accessing information systems unless an exemption applies.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.name: Remote Access MFA Requirement
list_bullet_points.text: (1) remote access to the covered entity’s information systems;
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point specifies the requirement for multi-factor authentication for remote access to the covered entity’s information systems.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.name: Third-party Applications MFA Requirement
list_bullet_points.text:
(2) remote access to third-party applications, including but not limited to those that are 
cloud based, from which nonpublic information is accessible;
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point outlines the requirement for multi-factor authentication for remote access to third-party applications that contain nonpublic information.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.name: Privileged Accounts MFA Requirement
list_bullet_points.text: (3) all privileged accounts other than service accounts that prohibit interactive login.
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point specifies that multi-factor authentication is required for all privileged accounts, excluding service accounts that prohibit interactive login.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.text:

equivalent or more secure compensating controls. Such controls shall be reviewed periodically,

list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point allows for the CISO to approve alternative controls to multi-factor authentication, provided they are reasonably equivalent or more secure and are reviewed at least annually.
list_bullet_points.context: 500.12 Multi-factor authentication.

list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point specifies the requirement for a method to track key information for each asset as part of asset management policies.

list_bullet_points.text:

other legitimate business purposes of the covered entity, except where such information is

list_bullet_points.description: Retention of information when legally required or when disposal is infeasible.
list_bullet_points.context: Disposal of unnecessary information or when its retention is compulsory by law.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Monitoring
list_bullet_points.description: Implementing controls to monitor authorized users' activities and prevent unauthorized access.
list_bullet_points.context: Covered entities must have monitoring procedures as part of their cybersecurity program.

list_bullet_points.name: Protection Against Malicious Code
list_bullet_points.text:
implement risk-based controls designed to protect against malicious code, including 
those that monitor and filter web traffic and electronic mail to block malicious content;
list_bullet_points.description: Instituting risk-based measures to protect systems from malicious code and content.
list_bullet_points.context: Cybersecurity program requirements to protect against malicious threats.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity Awareness Training
list_bullet_points.text:
provide periodic, but at a minimum annual, cybersecurity awareness training that 
includes social engineering for all personnel that is updated to reflect risks identified by 
the covered entity in its risk assessment.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement for annual cybersecurity awareness training for all personnel.
list_bullet_points.context: Training programs as a component of cybersecurity defenses.

list_bullet_points.name: Class A Company Security Measures
list_bullet_points.text:
Each class A company shall implement, unless the CISO has approved in writing the use of 
reasonably equivalent or more secure compensating controls: 
(1) an endpoint detection and response solution to monitor anomalous activity, including 
but not limited to lateral movement; and 
(2) a solution that centralizes logging and security event alerting.
list_bullet_points.description: Specific security solutions for class A companies to monitor activities and centralize logging.
list_bullet_points.context: Mandatory security infrastructure for class A companies unless alternative measures are approved by the CISO.

list_bullet_points.name: Encryption Policy
list_bullet_points.text:
each covered entity shall implement a written policy 
requiring encryption that meets industry standards, to protect nonpublic information held or 
transmitted by the covered entity both in transit over external networks and at rest.
list_bullet_points.description: Mandatory encryption policies to protect nonpublic information during transmission and storage.
list_bullet_points.context: Cybersecurity program requirements for protecting sensitive data.

list_bullet_points.name: Alternative to Encryption
list_bullet_points.text:
To the extent a covered entity determines that encryption of nonpublic information at rest is 
infeasible, the covered entity may instead secure such nonpublic information using effective 
alternative compensating controls that have been reviewed and approved by the covered entity’s 
CISO in writing. The feasibility of encryption and effectiveness of the compensating controls 
shall be reviewed by the CISO at least annually.
list_bullet_points.description: Allowing alternative measures to encryption if deemed infeasible, with annual reviews by the CISO.
list_bullet_points.context: Options for securing nonpublic information when standard encryption is not practical.

list_bullet_points.text: identify documents, data, facilities, infrastructure, services, personnel and competencies essential to the continued operations of the covered entity’s business;
list_bullet_points.description: Recognizing all crucial components necessary for business operations continuity.
