list_bullet_points.text: include a plan to communicate with essential persons in the event of a cybersecurity-related disruption to the operations of the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Crafting strategies for communication during a cybersecurity-induced disruption of normal business activities.
list_bullet_points.context: BCDR plans shall be reasonably designed to ensure the availability and functionality of the covered entity’s information systems and material services and protect the covered entity’s personnel, assets and nonpublic information...

list_bullet_points.name: Recovery Plans
list_bullet_points.text: include procedures for the timely recovery of critical data and information systems and to resume operations as soon as reasonably possible following a cybersecurity-related disruption to normal business activities
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point highlights the requirement for timely recovery of critical data and resumption of operations following a disruption.
list_bullet_points.context: Cybersecurity plans must include procedures for both recovery of data and resumption of operations post-disruption.

list_bullet_points.name: Backup Procedures
list_bullet_points.text: include procedures for backing up or copying, with sufficient frequency, information essential to the operations of the covered entity and storing such information offsite
list_bullet_points.description: The requirement here is to ensure essential information is backed up or copied frequently and stored offsite.
list_bullet_points.context: Cybersecurity measures must include backup strategies for essential data.

list_bullet_points.name: Third Party Identification
list_bullet_points.text: identify third parties that are necessary to the continued operations of the covered entity’s information systems
list_bullet_points.description: This bullet point requires the identification of third-parties crucial to information systems' operations.
list_bullet_points.context: Covered entities need to recognize third-party dependencies in their operations.

list_bullet_points.name: Availability of Recovery Plans
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall ensure that current copies of the plans or relevant portions therein are distributed or are otherwise accessible, including during a cybersecurity event, to all employees necessary to implement such plans.
list_bullet_points.description: The necessity to make recovery plans or portions accessible to key employees during cybersecurity events.
list_bullet_points.context: Plans must be readily accessible to those responsible during cybersecurity incidents.

list_bullet_points.name: Employee Training
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall provide relevant training to all employees responsible for implementing the plans regarding their roles and responsibilities.
list_bullet_points.description: Training requirement for employees on their roles and responsibilities in plan implementation.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures personnel are prepared to effectively execute cybersecurity and recovery plans.

list_bullet_points.name: Plan Testing
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall periodically, but at a minimum annually, test its: incident response and BCDR plans with all staff and management critical to the response, and shall revise the plan as necessary
list_bullet_points.description: Regular testing of incident response and BCDR plans is required, with revisions as necessary.
list_bullet_points.context: Annual tests ensure plans are effective and up-to-date.

list_bullet_points.name: Data Restoration Testing
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall periodically, but at a minimum annually, test its: ability to restore its critical data and information systems from backups.
list_bullet_points.description: Annual testing of data restoration from backups is necessary to ensure recoverability.
list_bullet_points.context: Reflects importance of backup efficacy in recovery efforts.

list_bullet_points.name: Protected Backups
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall maintain backups necessary to restore material operations. The backups shall be adequately protected from unauthorized alterations or destruction.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirement to maintain and protect backups for operational restoration purposes.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures the integrity and availability of backups during recovery.

list_bullet_points.name: Incident Notification Timeline
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall notify the superintendent electronically in the form set forth on the department’s website as promptly as possible but in no event later than 72 hours after determining that a cybersecurity incident has occurred at the covered entity, its affiliates, or a third-party service provider.
list_bullet_points.description: Mandatory 72-hour notification window following detection of cybersecurity incidents.
list_bullet_points.context: Regulation enforces prompt reporting of incidents to authorities.

list_bullet_points.name: Ongoing Incident Updates
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity shall promptly provide to the superintendent any information requested regarding such incident. Covered entities shall have a continuing obligation to update the superintendent with material changes or new information previously unavailable.
list_bullet_points.description: Continued updates to the superintendent about any material changes or new information regarding incidents are required.
list_bullet_points.context: Ensures transparency and continuous communication with regulatory bodies post-incident.

list_bullet_points.name: Annual compliance certification or acknowledgment
list_bullet_points.text: (1) Annually each covered entity shall submit to the superintendent electronically by April 15 either: (i) a written certification that: (a) certifies that the covered entity materially complied with the requirements set forth in this Part during the prior calendar year; and (b) shall be based upon data and documentation sufficient to accurately determine and demonstrate such material compliance, including, to the extent necessary, documentation of officers, employees, representatives, outside vendors and other individuals or entities, as well as other documentation, whether in the form of reports, certifications, schedules or otherwise; or (ii) a written acknowledgment that: (a) acknowledges that, for the prior calendar year, the covered entity did not materially comply with all the requirements of this Part; (b) identifies all sections of this Part that the entity has not materially complied with and describes the nature and extent of such noncompliance; and (c) provides a remediation timeline or confirmation that remediation has been completed.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities must annually submit a certification of compliance or an acknowledgment of noncompliance with a remediation timeline, by April 15.
list_bullet_points.context: Compliance documentation and submission requirements for covered entities.

list_bullet_points.name: Electronic submission and signature requirements
list_bullet_points.text: (2) Such certification or acknowledgment shall be submitted electronically in the form set forth on the department’s website and shall be signed by the covered entity’s highest-ranking executive and its CISO. If the covered entity does not have a CISO, the certification or acknowledgment shall be signed by the highest-ranking executive and by the senior officer responsible for the cybersecurity program of the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Certifications or acknowledgments must be submitted electronically and appropriately signed by designated officers.
list_bullet_points.context: Compliance documentation submission protocol and authentication requirements.

list_bullet_points.name: Record maintenance and inspection
list_bullet_points.text: (3) Each covered entity shall maintain for examination and inspection by the department upon request all records, schedules and other documentation and data supporting the certification or acknowledgment for a period of five years, including the identification of all areas, systems and processes that require or required material improvement, updating or redesign, all remedial efforts undertaken to address such areas, systems and processes, and remediation plans and timelines for their implementation.
list_bullet_points.description: Covered entities are required to keep all supporting documentation for certifications or acknowledgments for five years.
list_bullet_points.context: Record-keeping and inspection preparedness requirements for covered entities.

list_bullet_points.name: Notice of extortion payment
list_bullet_points.text: (c) Notice and explanation of extortion payment. Each covered entity, in the event of an extortion payment made in connection with a cybersecurity event involving the covered entity, shall provide the superintendent electronically, in the form set forth on the department’s website, with the following:
list_bullet_points.description: Entities must notify and explain extortion payments made due to cybersecurity events.
list_bullet_points.context: Reporting obligations related to extortion payments connected with cybersecurity incidents.

list_bullet_points.name: Extortion Payment Notification
list_bullet_points.text: (1) within 24 hours of the extortion payment, notice of the payment; and (2) within 30 days of the extortion payment, a written description of the reasons payment was necessary, a description of alternatives to payment considered, all diligence performed to find alternatives to payment and all diligence performed to ensure compliance with applicable rules and regulations.
list_bullet_points.description: Entities must notify within 24 hours of an extortion payment, and provide a detailed report within 30 days.
list_bullet_points.context: Regarding the reporting requirements following an extortion payment, entities must adhere to a strict timeline for initial notice and subsequent detailed reporting.

list_bullet_points.name: Confidentiality
list_bullet_points.text: Information provided by a covered entity pursuant to this Part is subject to exemptions from disclosure under the Banking Law, Insurance Law, Financial Services Law, Public Officers Law or any other applicable State or Federal law.
list_bullet_points.description: Information supplied by entities under the regulation is protected by several laws ensuring confidentiality.
list_bullet_points.context: This section outlines the confidentiality protections under which the provided information is secured.

list_bullet_points.name: Limited Exemption for Small Entities
list_bullet_points.text: Each covered entity with: (1) fewer than 20 employees and independent contractors of the covered entity and its affiliates; (2) less than $7,500,000 in gross annual revenue in each of the last three fiscal years from all business operations of the covered entity and the business operations in this State of the covered entity’s affiliates; or (3) less than $15,000,000 in year-end total assets, calculated in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, including assets of all affiliates, shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 500.4, 500.5, 500.6, 500.8, 500.10, 500.14(a)(1), (a)(2), and (b), 500.15 and 500.16 of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Small entities under certain thresholds are exempt from specific sections of the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: This exemption clause outlines which small entities can claim exemptions from the cybersecurity regulations based on employee numbers, revenue, and assets criteria.

list_bullet_points.name: Exemption for Employees and Agents
list_bullet_points.text: An employee, agent, wholly owned subsidiary, representative or designee of a covered entity, who is itself a covered entity, is exempt from this Part and need not develop its own cybersecurity program to the extent that the employee, agent, wholly owned subsidiary, representative or designee is covered by the cybersecurity program of the covered entity.
list_bullet_points.description: Affiliated employees and agents do not need separate cybersecurity programs if covered by the main entity.
list_bullet_points.context: The regulation permits exemptions for certain connected individuals and entities under a larger covered entity’s cybersecurity program.

list_bullet_points.name: Exemption for Non-Information Handling Entities
list_bullet_points.text: A covered entity that does not directly or indirectly operate, maintain, utilize or control any information systems, and that does not, and is not required to, directly or indirectly control, own, access, generate, receive or possess nonpublic information shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 500.2, 500.3, 500.4, 500.5, 500.6, 500.7, 500.8, 500.10, 500.12, 500.14, 500.15 and 500.16 of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Entities not handling any information systems or nonpublic information are exempt from major sections of the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: This specifies the exemption for entities that do not manage information systems or sensitive information, thus not requiring compliance with most cybersecurity protocols.

list_bullet_points.name: Individual Insurance Broker Exemption
list_bullet_points.text: (e) An individual insurance broker subject to Insurance Law section 2104 who qualifies for the exemption pursuant to subdivision 500.19(c) of this Part and has not, for any compensation, commission or other thing of value, acted or aided in any manner in soliciting, negotiating or selling any policy or contract or in placing risks or taking out insurance on behalf of another person for at least one year shall be exempt from the requirements of this Part, provided such individuals do not otherwise qualify as a covered entity for purposes of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Exempts individual insurance brokers from cybersecurity requirements if they meet certain conditions outlined under Insurance Law and haven't engaged in transactions for over a year.
list_bullet_points.context: Discusses the scenarios under which individual insurance brokers may be exempt from cybersecurity requirements.

list_bullet_points.name: Notice of Exemption Filing
list_bullet_points.text: (f) A covered entity that qualifies for any of the above exemptions pursuant to this section shall file electronically a Notice of Exemption in the form set forth on the department’s website within 30 days of the determination that the covered entity is exempt.
list_bullet_points.description: Mandates covered entities that are exempt from certain requirements to file a Notice of Exemption within a specified time frame.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies procedural requirements for entities that are exempt from parts of the regulation.

list_bullet_points.name: Exempt Persons
list_bullet_points.text: (g) The following persons are exempt from the requirements of this Part, provided such persons do not otherwise qualify as a covered entity for purposes of this Part: persons subject to Insurance Law section 1110; persons subject to Insurance Law section 5904; any accredited reinsurer, certified reinsurer or reciprocal jurisdiction reinsurer that has been so recognized pursuant to 11 NYCRR Part 125; individual insurance agents who are placed in inactive status under Insurance Law section 2103; and individual licensees placed in inactive status under Banking Law section 599-i.
list_bullet_points.description: Lists specific exemptions from the cybersecurity regulations applicable to certain individuals and insurers as per New York laws.
list_bullet_points.context: Details the specific categories of persons who are exempt from the regulation provided they are not covered entities.

list_bullet_points.name: Loss of Exemption Qualification
list_bullet_points.text: (h) In the event that a covered entity ceases to qualify for an exemption, such covered entity shall have 180 days from the date that it ceases to so qualify to comply with all applicable requirements of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Provides a grace period for entities that lose their exempt status to comply with all applicable cybersecurity requirements.
list_bullet_points.context: Instructions for covered entities that no longer qualify for an exemption and need to meet all regulatory requirements.

list_bullet_points.name: Regulation Enforcement
list_bullet_points.text: 500.20 Enforcement. (a) This regulation will be enforced by the superintendent pursuant to, and is not intended to limit, the superintendent’s authority under any applicable laws.
list_bullet_points.description: Clarifies the enforcement authority and intent behind the regulation, emphasizing the superintendent's enforcement role.
list_bullet_points.context: Introduction to the enforcement section, highlighting jurisdiction and authority of the superintendent.

list_bullet_points.name: Violation Definition
list_bullet_points.text: (b) The commission of a single act prohibited by this Part or the failure to act to satisfy an obligation required by this Part shall constitute a violation hereof. Such acts or failures include, without limitation: (1) the failure to secure or prevent unauthorized access to an individual’s or an entity’s nonpublic information due to noncompliance with any section of this Part; or (2) the material failure to comply for any 24-hour period with any section of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Defines what constitutes a violation of the regulation, including failure to secure nonpublic information and failure to comply with any part for 24 hours.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies conditions and examples of regulatory violations.

list_bullet_points.name: Penalty Assessment Factors
list_bullet_points.text: (c) In assessing any penalty for a violation of this Part pursuant to the Banking Law, Insurance Law or Financial Services Law, the superintendent shall take into account, without limitation, factors including: (1) the extent to which the covered entity has cooperated with the superintendent in the investigation of such acts;
list_bullet_points.description: Outlines considerations for penalty assessments which include the degree of cooperation with the investigation.
list_bullet_points.context: Discusses factors that influence the determination of penalties for regulatory violations.

list_bullet_points.name: Good faith of the entity
list_bullet_points.text: (2) the good faith of the entity;
list_bullet_points.description: Consideration of whether the entity acted in good faith during violations.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Nature of Violations
list_bullet_points.text: (3) whether the violations resulted from conduct that was unintentional or inadvertent, reckless or intentional and deliberate;
list_bullet_points.description: Considering if the violation was unintentional, reckless, or intentional.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Remedy of previous matters
list_bullet_points.text: (4) whether the violation was a result of failure to remedy previous examination matters requiring attention, or failing to adhere to any disciplinary letter, letter of instructions or similar;
list_bullet_points.description: Assesses if violations were due to failure in addressing past examination concerns or instructions.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: History of prior violations
list_bullet_points.text: (5) any history of prior violations;
list_bullet_points.description: Assessing any previous violation history of the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Violation pattern
list_bullet_points.text: (6) whether the violation involved an isolated incident, repeat violations, systemic violations or a pattern of violations;
list_bullet_points.description: Evaluating if the violation was isolated or part of a repeated or systemic pattern.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: False information
list_bullet_points.text: (7) whether the covered entity provided false or misleading information;
list_bullet_points.description: Determining if false or misleading information was provided by the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Consumer harm
list_bullet_points.text: (8) the extent of harm to consumers;
list_bullet_points.description: Assessing the level of harm caused to consumers by the violation.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Disclosures to consumers
list_bullet_points.text: (9) whether required, accurate and timely disclosures were made to affected consumers;
list_bullet_points.description: Evaluating if proper disclosures were timely made to consumers.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Gravity of violations
list_bullet_points.text: (10) the gravity of the violations;
list_bullet_points.description: Assessing the seriousness of the violations committed by the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Duration and number of violations
list_bullet_points.text: (11) the number of violations and the length of time over which they occurred;
list_bullet_points.description: Considering the number and duration of violations.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Senior body participation
list_bullet_points.text: (12) the extent, if any, to which the senior governing body participated therein;
list_bullet_points.description: Evaluating the involvement of senior management in the violations.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Regulatory penalty
list_bullet_points.text: (13) any penalty or sanction imposed by any other regulatory agency;
list_bullet_points.description: Considering penalties or sanctions from other regulatory agencies.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Financial resources of entity
list_bullet_points.text: (14) the financial resources, net worth and annual business volume of the covered entity and its affiliates;
list_bullet_points.description: Assessing the financial capacity and resources of the entity.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Cybersecurity frameworks alignment
list_bullet_points.text: (15) the extent to which the relevant policies and procedures of the company are consistent with nationally recognized cybersecurity frameworks, such as NIST; and
list_bullet_points.description: Evaluating alignment with recognized cybersecurity standards.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Other matters for justice
list_bullet_points.text: (16) such other matters as justice and the public interest require.
list_bullet_points.description: Considering any other justice or public interest matters.
list_bullet_points.context: Determining factors for assessing violations by an entity.

list_bullet_points.name: Effective date of compliance
list_bullet_points.text: 500.21 Effective date. (a) This Part will be effective March 1, 2017. Covered entities will be required to annually prepare and submit to the superintendent a certification of compliance with New York State Department of Financial Services Cybersecurity Regulations under section 500.17(b) of this Part commencing February 15, 2018.
list_bullet_points.description: Initial effective date and compliance certification start date.
list_bullet_points.context: Timeline for compliance to the regulations.

list_bullet_points.name: Second amendment effective date
list_bullet_points.text: (b) The second amendment to this Part shall become effective November 1, 2023.
list_bullet_points.description: The effective date for the second amendment to the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Timeline for compliance to the regulations.

list_bullet_points.name: General Transitional Period for Compliance
list_bullet_points.text: Covered entities shall have 180 days from the effective date of this Part to comply with the requirements set forth in this Part, except as otherwise specified.
list_bullet_points.description: Provides a general transitional period of 180 days for covered entities to comply with the new cybersecurity requirements, unless stated otherwise.
list_bullet_points.context: Explains the timeline covered entities have to adhere to the cybersecurity requirements after the regulation takes effect.

list_bullet_points.name: One Year Transitional Period
list_bullet_points.text: (1) one year from the effective date of this Part to comply with the requirements of sections 500.4(b), 500.5, 500.9, 500.12 and 500.14(b) of this Part;
list_bullet_points.description: Allows covered entities one year to comply with specified sections of the regulation from its effective date.
list_bullet_points.context: Specifies sections of the regulation that have a one-year compliance deadline from the effective date.

list_bullet_points.name: Eighteen Months Transitional Period
list_bullet_points.text: (2) eighteen months from the effective date of this Part to comply with the requirements of sections 500.6, 500.8, 500.13, 500.14(a) and 500.15 of this Part;
list_bullet_points.description: Requires compliance with certain sections within 18 months from the effective date.
list_bullet_points.context: Details the compliance timeframe for specific regulatory sections extended to 18 months.

list_bullet_points.name: Two Years Transitional Period
list_bullet_points.text: (3) two years from the effective date of this Part to comply with the requirements of section 500.11 of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Sets a two-year transition for compliance with section 500.11.
list_bullet_points.context: Outlines the longest transitional period requiring compliance at two years for a specific section.

list_bullet_points.name: Second Amendment Transitional Period
list_bullet_points.text: Covered entities shall have 180 days from the effective date of the second amendment to this Part to comply with the new requirements set forth in the second amendment to this Part, except as otherwise specified in subdivisions (d) and (e) below.
list_bullet_points.description: Gives 180 days from the amendment's effective date to adhere to new requirements, with exceptions noted.
list_bullet_points.context: Introduces new requirements with a prescribed compliance period following a regulation amendment.

list_bullet_points.name: 30 Days Transitional Period for Second Amendment
list_bullet_points.text: (1) 30 days from the effective date of the second amendment to this Part to comply with the new requirements specified in section 500.17 of this Part;
list_bullet_points.description: Mandates compliance within 30 days for a specific section post-amendment.
list_bullet_points.context: Highlights a short compliance window for a specific requirement following a regulatory amendment.

list_bullet_points.name: One Year Transitional Period for Second Amendment
list_bullet_points.text: (2) one year from the effective date of the second amendment to this Part to comply with the new requirements specified in sections 500.4, 500.15, 500.16 and 500.19(a) of this Part;
list_bullet_points.description: Provides one year for compliance with several sections following the second amendment.
list_bullet_points.context: Aligns compliance deadlines for multiple sections post-amendment to one year.

list_bullet_points.name: 18 Months Transitional Period for Second Amendment
list_bullet_points.text: (3) 18 months from the effective date of the second amendment to this Part to comply with the new requirements specified in sections 500.5(a)(2), 500.7, 500.14(a)(2) and 500.14(b) of this Part;
list_bullet_points.description: Specifies an 18-month compliance timeframe for sections following the second amendment.
list_bullet_points.context: Allows for an extended timeline of 18 months for compliance with selected sections after an amendment.

list_bullet_points.name: Two Years Transitional Period for Second Amendment
list_bullet_points.text: (4) two years from the effective date of the second amendment to this Part to comply with the new requirements specified in sections 500.12 and 500.13(a) of this Part.
list_bullet_points.description: Extends the compliance period to two years for specific sections post-amendment.
list_bullet_points.context: Provides a maximum transition period following an amendment for certain sections.

list_bullet_points.name: November 1, 2023 - New Requirements Effective Date
list_bullet_points.text: The new requirements specified in sections 500.19(e)-(h), 500.20, 500.21, 500.22 and 500.24 of this Part shall become effective November 1, 2023.
list_bullet_points.description: Sets the effective date for new requirements to November 1, 2023.
list_bullet_points.context: Defines when new regulatory sections come into effect.

list_bullet_points.name: Severability Clause
list_bullet_points.text: If any provision of this Part or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not affect or impair the validity of the other provisions of this Part or the application thereof to other persons or circumstances.
list_bullet_points.description: This clause ensures that if one part of the regulation is found invalid, the rest remains in effect.
list_bullet_points.context: Addresses the legal durability of the regulation in face of partial invalidity rulings.

list_bullet_points.name: Electronic Filing Exemption Application
list_bullet_points.text: A filer required to make an electronic filing or a submission pursuant to this Part may apply to the superintendent for an exemption from the requirement that the filing or submission be electronic by submitting a written request to the superintendent for approval at least 30 days before the filer shall submit to the superintendent the particular filing or submission that is the subject of the request.
list_bullet_points.description: Procedure for applying for an exemption from electronic filing requirements.
list_bullet_points.context: Details the timeline and process for exemption requests.

list_bullet_points.name: Contents of Exemption Request
list_bullet_points.text: (1) set forth the filer’s DFS license number, NAIC number, Nationwide Multistate Licensing System number or institution number; (2) identify the specific filing or submission for which the filer is applying for the exemption; (3) specify whether the filer is making the request for an exemption based upon undue hardship, impracticability or good cause, and set forth a detailed explanation as to the reason that the superintendent should approve the request; and (4) specify whether the request for an exemption extends to future filings or submissions, in addition to the specific filing or submission identified in paragraph (2) of this subdivision.
list_bullet_points.description: Specific information required in an exemption request.
list_bullet_points.context: Outlines detailed requirements for obtaining electronic filing exemptions.

list_bullet_points.name: Superintendent's Authority for Exemption Evaluation
list_bullet_points.text: The filer requesting an exemption shall submit, upon the superintendent’s request, any additional information necessary for the superintendent to evaluate the filer’s request for an exemption.
list_bullet_points.description: Superintendent may request additional information to evaluate exemption applications.
list_bullet_points.context: Gives superintendent oversight over exemption process.

list_bullet_points.name: Conditions for Exemption Approval
list_bullet_points.text: The filer shall be exempt from the electronic filing or submission requirement upon the superintendent’s written determination so exempting the filer, where the determination specifies the basis upon which the superintendent is granting the request and to which filings or submissions the exemption applies.
list_bullet_points.description: Conditions under which an exemption from electronic filing is granted.
list_bullet_points.context: Outlines how exemptions are granted and their specific applicability.

list_bullet_points.name: Alternative Filing Requirements Post Exemption
list_bullet_points.text: If the superintendent approves a filer’s request for an exemption from the electronic filing or submission requirement, then the filer shall make a filing or submission in a form and manner acceptable to the superintendent.
list_bullet_points.description: Requirements for alternative filing methods upon exemption approval.
list_bullet_points.context: Establishes guidelines for non-electronic submission post exemption.

list_bullet_points.name: Repeal of Appendices A and B
list_bullet_points.text: Appendices A and B to 23 NYCRR 500 are hereby repealed.
list_bullet_points.description: Formal repeal of specific appendices in the regulation.
list_bullet_points.context: Announces repeal of particular supporting documents or guidelines.
